He suddenly shifted his expression and tone. 

He glanced around again. “You rent this room from the Kapernaumovs?” 

“Yeah…” 

“They live through that door?” 

“Yep. They have another room like this one.” 

“All in one room?” 

“Yeah.” 

“I’d be scared in your room at night,” he said darkly. 

“They're really nice people, very kind,” Sonia replied, still a bit dazed. “All the furniture, everything… it’s theirs. And the kids come to see me a lot.” 

“They all stammer, right?” 

“Yeah… the dad stammers and he’s lame. His wife doesn’t exactly stammer, but she can’t speak clearly. She’s super sweet. He used to be a house serf. They have seven kids… only the oldest stammers. The others are just sick, but they don’t stammer. How do you know about them?” she asked, surprised. 

“Your dad told me. He shared everything about you… how you left at six and came back at nine, and how Katerina Ivanovna knelt by your bed.” 

Sonia looked confused. “I thought I saw him today,” she said quietly. 

“Who?”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov visits Sonia for what he believes may be the last time, discussing her living situation and the kindness of her landlords.
